heading.title: PART III RIGHTS TO PROCEED IN ADMIRALTY [ss 14–26A]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART III RIGHTS TO PROCEED IN ADMIRALTY [ss 14–26A]
[250,100] s 14 Admiralty actions in rem to be commenced under this Act

leg:heading.title: Admiralty actions in rem to be commenced under this Act

p.text: In a matter of Admiralty or maritime jurisdiction, a proceeding shall not be commenced as an action in rem against a ship or other property except as provided by this Act.

The court is not prevented from entertaining an action in rem by reason only that the plaintiff has commenced other proceedings, at common law, claiming moneys the subject of the action in rem: HS Bird & Co Ltd v The Ship Karu (1925) 42 WN (NSW) 178 . Nor by reason only of common law proceedings commenced by the defendant: Union Steamship Co of New Zealand Ltd v The Ship Caradale (1937) 56 CLR 277 at 282; 10 ALJR 467 .

But where a party institutes duplicate proceedings a stay of one or other of those proceedings may be appropriate: Caloundra Boatyard Pty Ltd v The Almonta [1968] SASR 325 . See also Henry v Henry (1996) 185 CLR 571; 135 ALR 564; [1995] HCA 64; BC9601211 .

Where parties both belonging to a foreign state have taken the occasion of a ship being temporarily within the jurisdiction to litigate a question of title depending on the municipal laws of another country, the court may (in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction to dismiss or stay an action) decline to exercise its jurisdiction: The Courageous Coloctronis [1979] WAR 19 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,105] s 15 Right to proceed in rem on maritime liens etc

leg:heading.title: Right to proceed in rem on maritime liens etc

p.text: A proceeding on a maritime lien or other charge in respect of a ship or other property subject to the lien or charge may be commenced as an action in rem against the ship or property.
A reference in subsection (1) to a maritime lien includes a reference to a lien for:
salvage;
damage done by a ship;
wages of the master, or of a member of the crew, of a ship; or
master's disbursements.
Legislation cited in [250,105.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 15(2).

The inclusive definition in s 15(2) leaves open the possibility that, in addition to the enumerated liens, other maritime liens might be recognised at common law. The Act also leaves open the question whether a maritime lien should be recognised when the relevant act or event occurs outside the forum and gives rise to a maritime lien under the relevant foreign law but would not have done so under Australian law: see ALRC, Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986, para 123.
Legislation cited in [250,105.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(3)(r).

Although the right to bring an action in rem in respect of disbursements on account of a ship has been extended beyond the master to a shipper, charterer or agent (see s 4(3)(r) of the Admiralty Rules 1988 (Cth)), there has not been an extension of the corresponding master's lien. However, upon application made by a shipper, for example, to the court prior to the disbursement being incurred, the court may order that a lien be given on the ship for the amount of the disbursement plus interest: Keeney v The Aneiura [1927] VLR 387 at 390 (shipper obtained lien from court for provision made for sustenance of the crew).

level.toc-caption: [250,105.15] Lien holder as a secured creditor

heading.title: Lien holder as a secured creditor

p.text: Once a writ is issued for a maritime lien, and even if the writ has not been served, the plaintiff ranks as a secured creditor and will be given leave to proceed against the company owning the ship even if that company is in liquidation: see Re Aro Co Ltd [1980] Ch 196 at 205 .

level.toc-caption: [250,105.20] Other property subject to the lien

p.text: Legislation cited in [250,105.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 24.

heading.title: Other property subject to the lien

p.text: Apart from the express provision in s 24 for the commencement of an action against proceeds of sale in court, the Act does not specify, the “other property” in respect of which the action in rem can be commenced: see ALRC Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, paras 109–11.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,110] s 16 Right to proceed in rem on proprietary maritime claims

leg:heading.title: Right to proceed in rem on proprietary maritime claims

p.text: A proceeding on a proprietary maritime claim concerning a ship or other property may be commenced as an action in rem against the ship or property.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,115] s 17 Right to proceed in rem on owner's liabilities

leg:heading.title: Right to proceed in rem on owner's liabilities

p.text: Where in relation to a general maritime claim concerning a ship or other property, a relevant person:
was, when the cause of action arose, the owner or charterer of, or in possession or control of, the ship or property; and
is, when the proceeding is commenced, the owner of the ship or property;
a proceeding on the claim may be commenced as an action in rem against the ship or property.
Legislation cited in [250,115.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 15, s 16, s 17(a), (b), s 18, s 19, s 3(1).

In general, an action can be commenced in rem only if a relevant person, that is, the person who would be liable on the claim in a proceeding commenced in personam (see the definition in s 3(1) ), is the owner of the ship at the time the action is sought to be commenced: Shell Oil Co v The Ship Lastrigoni (1974) 131 CLR 1 at 5; 3 ALR 399 ; Dalgety & Co Ltd v Atchison (The Rose Pearl) (1957) 2 FLR 219; cf Fong Tai v Buchheister & Co [1908] AC 458 . For exceptions to this general proposition see s 15 (maritime liens), s 16 (proprietary maritime claims), s 18 (demise charter) and s 19 (proceeding against surrogate ship). Where an application is made to release a vessel from arrest, an arresting plaintiff will be required to establish the jurisdictional facts relating to ownership of the ship at the time specified in s 17(a) and (b) : Owners of Shin Kobe Maru v Empire Shipping Co Inc (1994) 181 CLR 404 at 426; 125 ALR 1; BC9404668 . In a challenge to the court's jurisdiction, it is not relevant to inquire into or assess the strength of the “relevant persons” in personam claim: KMP Coastal Oil Pty Ltd v Owners of MV Iran Amanat (1997) 75 FCR 78; 144 ALR 720 .

The term is not defined in the Act. Query whether it means beneficial owner as well as legal owner: see Kali Boat Building and Repair Pty Ltd v Bosna (1977) 19 SASR 112 at 114 ; cf The Evpo Agnic [1988] 3 All ER 810; [1988] 1 WLR 1090. “Owner” has been held to mean or include a beneficial owner who may not be the registered owner of the vessel: Malaysia Shipyard and Engineering SDN BHD v The Iron Shortland (1995) 59 FCR 535; 131 ALR 738 . Presumably the ordinary rules of company law would apply: cf The Maritime Trader [1981] 2 Lloyd's Rep 153 at 159 and ALRC, Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986, paras 138–41.
Legislation cited in [250,115.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 3(2).
Pursuant to s 3(2) proceedings are commenced on the filing of the originating process or upon its issue by the court.

A plaintiff intending to commence in rem proceedings should first carefully satisfy itself of the ownership of the vessel to be arrested: Lloyd Werft Bremerhaven GMBH v Owners of the Ship Zoya Kozmodenyanskaya (FCA, Tamberlin J, 15 May 1997, unreported, BC9701974).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,120] s 18 Right to proceed in rem on demise charterer's liabilities

leg:heading.title: Right to proceed in rem on demise charterer's liabilities

p.text: Where, in relation to a maritime claim concerning a ship, a relevant person:
was, when the cause of action arose, the owner or charterer, or in possession or control, of the ship; and
is, when the proceeding is commenced, a demise charterer of the ship;
a proceeding on the claim may be commenced as an action in rem against the ship.

Under a demise charter, the charterer becomes for the time being the owner of the vessel. If the services of the master and crew are added, they become the servants of the charterer and through them the charterer has possession of the ship: see Sandeman v Scurr (1866) LR 2 QB 86 at 96 and Scrutton on Charterparties, 19th ed, Sweet & Maxwell, London, 1984, p 47 ff.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,125] s 19 Right to proceed in rem against surrogate ship

leg:heading.title: Right to proceed in rem against surrogate ship

p.text: A proceeding on a general maritime claim concerning a ship may be commenced as an action in rem against some other ship if:
a relevant person in relation to the claim was, when the cause of action arose, the owner or charterer of, or in possession or control of, the first-mentioned ship; and
that person is, when the proceeding is commenced, the owner of the second-mentioned ship.

This section introduces into Australia, for the first time, the right to proceed in rem against a ship other than that in relation to which the claim arose. All co-owners of the surrogate ship must be relevant persons in relation to the original claim. The right is not available in respect of proprietary maritime claims. It is not sufficient if the other ship is merely chartered to the relevant person. Actions in rem against surrogate freight and cargo are not available.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,130] s 20 Service on and arrest of only one ship

leg:heading.title: Service on and arrest of only one ship

p.text: Where service of initiating process in a proceeding commenced as mentioned in section 15 , 17 , 18 or 19 has been effected on a ship, service of initiating process in the proceeding shall not be effected on any other ship unless the service on the first-mentioned ship has been set aside or the proceeding, so far as it relates to that ship, has been discontinued, dismissed or struck out.

Where service of initiating process in a proceeding commenced as mentioned in section 15 , 17 , 18 or 19 has been effected on a ship, service of initiating process in some other proceeding on the same claim commenced as mentioned in any of those sections shall not be effected on any other ship unless the first-mentioned proceeding has been discontinued, dismissed or struck out.
Where a ship has been arrested in a proceeding commenced as mentioned in section 15 , 17 , 18 or 19 , no other ship shall be arrested in the proceeding unless the first-mentioned ship:
was invalidly arrested and has been released from arrest; or
was unlawfully removed from the custody of the Marshal and the Marshal has not regained custody of the ship.
Where:
a person has a claim that is both:
a claim on a maritime lien or other charge; and
a general maritime claim;
in respect of a ship; and

subsection (3) does not prevent the arrest of the first-mentioned ship in a proceeding on the maritime lien or other charge if the amount recovered by the person in the proceeding commenced under section 19 is less than the amount of the claim on the maritime lien or other charge.
Legislation cited in [250,130.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Rules 1988 Admiralty Rules 1988 (Cth) r 16.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 19, s 20(4).

The initiating process may identify the ship, the subject of the claim, and one or more surrogate ships: see Admiralty Rules 1988 (Cth) r 16 . The plaintiff may wait until it finds the ship which is most suitable to arrest, but in general it cannot then go against the other named ships. Section 20(4) provides an exception where the amount recovered in the s 19 proceedings is less than the amount originally claimed.

A ship or other property arrested in a proceeding on a maritime claim may not be re-arrested in the proceeding in relation to the claim unless the court so orders, whether because default has been made in the performance of a guarantee or undertaking given to procure the release of the ship or property from the earlier arrest or for some other sufficient reason.
An order under subsection (1) may be made subject to such conditions as are just.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,137] s 22 Service and arrest out of jurisdiction

leg:heading.title: Service and arrest out of jurisdiction

p.text: Subject to subsection (4) :
initiating process in a proceeding commenced as an action in rem in the Federal Court may be served on a ship or other property; and
a ship or other property may be arrested in such a proceeding;
at any place within Australia, including a place within the limits of the territorial sea of Australia.
Subject to subsection (4) , initiating process in a proceeding commenced as an action in rem in a court of a State or a Territory may be served on a ship or other property:

if, at a time when the process was effective for service, the ship or property was within the locality within which the court may exercise jurisdiction — at any place within Australia, including a place within the limits of the territorial sea of Australia; or
in any case — at any place within the State or Territory, including a place within the limits of the territorial sea of Australia that is adjacent to the State or Territory.

Subject to subsection (4) , in a proceeding commenced as an action in rem in a court of a State or Territory, a ship or other property may be arrested at any place within Australia, including a place within the limits of the territorial sea of Australia.

Where the arrest of a foreign ship, or of cargo on board a foreign ship, would be inconsistent with a right of innocent passage that is being exercised by the ship, this Act does not authorise the service of process on the ship or the arrest of the ship or cargo.
In this section:
has the meaning it has under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea done at Montego Bay on 10 December 1982.
[subs (5) am Act 20 of 1994 s 15 and Sch 1]
For the Convention on the Law of the Sea see the Schedule to the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973.
[s 22 am Act 20 of 1994 s 15 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,140] s 23 Service and Execution of Process Act not to apply

leg:heading.title: Service and Execution of Process Act not to apply

p.text: The Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 does not apply to the service of initiating process on, or the arrest of, a ship or other property under this Act.
[s 23 am Act 166 of 1992 s 5 and Sch]

Where, but for the sale of a ship or other property under this Act, a proceeding could have been commenced as an action in rem against the ship or property, the proceeding may be commenced as an action in rem against the proceeds of the sale that have been paid into a court under this Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,150] s 25 Limitation of liability under Liability Conventions

leg:heading.title: Limitation of liability under Liability Conventions

p.text: A person who apprehends that a claim for compensation under a law (including a law of a State or a Territory) that gives effect to provisions of a Liability Convention may be made against the person by some other person may apply to the Federal Court to determine the question whether the liability of the first-mentioned person in respect of the claim may be limited under that law.
Subsection (1) does not affect the jurisdiction of any other court.
On an application under subsection (1) , the Federal Court may, in accordance with the law referred to in that subsection:
determine whether the applicant's liability may be so limited and, if it may be so limited, determine the limit of that liability;
order the constitution of a limitation fund for the payment of claims in respect of which the applicant is entitled to limit his or her liability; and
make such orders as are just with respect to the administration and distribution of that fund.

Where a court has jurisdiction under this Act in respect of a proceeding, that jurisdiction extends to entertaining a defence in the proceeding by way of limitation of liability under a law that gives effect to provisions of a Liability Convention.
Legislation cited in [250,150.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Navigation Act 1912 s 335.
(CTH) Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 s 10.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 25(1)–(3).

A limitation action is one whereby an owner of a ship seeks to limit his or her liability in accordance with international conventions on the ground that there was no “actual fault or privity” on its part in respect of the acts forming the basis of the underlying claim. The action may be commenced in personam by the shipowner, in relation to existing or apprehended claims, or may be brought by way of a defence in proceedings in rem or in personam against the shipowner. The state and territory Supreme Courts already have jurisdiction in such proceedings: see Navigation Act 1912 (Cth) s 335 ; Protection of Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 (Cth) s 10 . Under the Admiralty Act 1988 :
all courts invested with admiralty jurisdiction, that is, including the District Court and Local Courts, may entertain a defence (only) by way of limitation of liability.
A limitation decree operates on claims that have passed judgment as well as those not yet determined: see James Patrick and Co Ltd v Union Steamship Co of New Zealand Ltd (1938) 60 CLR 650 at 673 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,155] s 26 Proceedings under Civil Liability Convention

p.text: A proceeding under this Act on a maritime claim referred to in paragraph 4(3)(b) shall not be brought otherwise than in accordance with paragraphs 1 and 3 of Article IX of the Civil Liability Convention, whether or not the proceeding also relates to a maritime claim or to a maritime lien or other charge.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,160] s 26A Proceedings in accordance with the Bunker Oil Convention

leg:heading.title: Proceedings in accordance with the Bunker Oil Convention

p.text: A proceeding under this Act on a maritime claim referred to in paragraph 4(3)(ba) must not be brought otherwise than in accordance with paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 9 of the Bunker Oil Convention, whether or not the proceeding also relates to another maritime claim or to a maritime lien or other charge.
In this section:
has the same meaning as in the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability for Bunker Oil Pollution Damage) Act 2008.
[s 26A insrt Act 77 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 16 June 2009]
